Definition: HyperText Transfer Protocol, the foundation of data communication for the World Wide Web.
JavaScript Object Notation, a lightweight data-interchange format that's easy for humans to read and write.
Representational State Transfer, an architectural style for designing networked applications.
Data Transfer Object, a design pattern used to transfer data between software application subsystems.
An open-source object-relational mapping framework for ADO.NET, part of the .NET framework.
Software that acts as a bridge between an operating system or database and applications, especially on a network.
The process of directing an HTTP request to the appropriate controller and action method in a web application.
Cross-Origin Resource Sharing, a mechanism that allows resources on a web page to be requested from another domain.
A design pattern that allows a class to receive its dependencies from external sources rather than creating them itself.
A class in ASP.NET that handles HTTP requests and returns responses.
A class that represents the data structure or entity in an application.
A model specifically designed to hold the data for the view.
A return type in ASP.NET MVC that encapsulates the result of an action method.
An interface that defines a contract for the result of an action method.
Language Integrated Query, a .NET component that adds native data querying capabilities.
A cross-platform, high-performance framework for building modern cloud-based web applications.
A markup syntax for embedding server-based code into webpages.
A library for ASP.NET developers to add real-time web functionality to applications.
An open-source framework for describing, producing, and consuming RESTful web services using OpenAPI.
Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) is a programming paradigm based on the concept of objects.
